text: I think it's more interesting to start from "what is the best possible media for communicating this system" and then work backward toward a "language". A natural language by itself is a pretty poor way to communicate complex systems. My example of this approach: <http://glench.github.io/fuzzyset.js/ui/>

attachments.title: Fuzzyset
attachments.text: An interactive human-readable visualization of a code library

text: I think it's more important to ask do we even want VR to be a thing? Why would we want a computing medium that even further disconnects us from our bodies and the world?

elements.text: I think it's more important to ask do we even want VR to be a thing? Why would we want a computing medium that even further disconnects us from our bodies and the world?

text: If you have the best possible media and the best possible language you ain't need no additional documentation. :joy:

elements.text: If you have the best possible media and the best possible language you ain't need no additional documentation.

text:
I think that CLI is the future, and I'm only half-joking.

I tend to think that, as people get more accustomed to computing, they will be increasingly find spatial/graphical interfaces cumbersome and start preferring more abstract interfaces, just like programmers. Today's average PC users are already familiar with abstract notions like file formats, cookies or 2FA. I think this tendency will accelerate and CLI-like interface will come back as a dominant style in future.

text:
<https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1627898272021500?thread_ts=1627619468.003300&cid=C5T9GPWFL|https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1627898272021500?thread_ts=1627619468.003300&cid=C5T9GPWFL>

I mean it is a thing so what "we" want is irrelevant. But more seriously, VR actually connects use more closely with our bodies than any other form of computing. There is a reason why fitness is one of the larger growth areas in VR. This comment seems guided by an idea of VR rather than the reality of current hardware. Arguably VR does heavily disconnect you from the world but it doesn't have to. That might start to get into XR spectrum, where does VR end and AR begin, etc debates though

text:
<https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1627868694020900?thread_ts=1627619468.003300&cid=C5T9GPWFL|https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1627868694020900?thread_ts=1627619468.003300&cid=C5T9GPWFL>

Curious about what is significantly less plug in play about current VR systems than a monitor. I understand it's not a standard approach, so it appears complicated. But in order to use my monitor effectively I still have to install GPU drivers (I understand that depending on your use case that might not be true). People often use coded language with VR to describe one thing, when they actually mean something else. So "not plug in play" could actually mean setup is easy, but the existing UX for interacting with traditional 2D applications is insufficient (which I agree with). This was my point that it's not just a monitor. In that sense even a monitor isn't just a monitor. You're working with decades of UX designed to make the monitor work and input systems designed to work with it. VR does have decades of research behind it, but modern consumer VR is only 5 years old...

attachments.fallback: [August 1st, 2021 6:44 PM] moodyharsh: Too many messages :slightly_smiling_face: I just saw a video of facebook’s scripting language. It seems to be a scratch derivate. Neat. Checkout the video posted by <@UML4ZEKDK> .. thats exactly what I want with plug and play, just like monitors. From the youtube comments you can see that plenty of people want the exact same thing. One a side note I don’t like notion that everything has to be fit into the mass market. I would be perfectly happy with the initial cardboard model where people were building their own vr headgear.
